title: Stop Using Solar Temporarily, Urges CEB
content: The Ceylon Electricity Board CEB is requesting all rooftop solar owners across the country to voluntarily switch off their solar systems during daytime hours until 3:00 PM each day from April 13through April 21. Due to the extended holiday period and sunny weather, national electricity demand has plummeted to historic lows, while very high Variable Renewable Energy VRE contribution is placing an extraordinary stress on the national grid, said the CEB on Saturday 12. As a result, the grid inertia has critically reduced, leaving it highly vulnerable to sudden disruptions, warned the CEB adding that even a minor fluctuation could trigger partial outages or a nationwide blackout.

title: Delhi Dust Storm Hits Airport Operations, 205 Flights Delayed
content: Strong dust winds swept across Delhi and its surrounding areas yesterday 11.The adverse weather conditions have disrupted flight operations at airports with at least 205 flights being delayed and at least 50 flights diverted from their scheduled destination. A strong dust storm whipped up Delhi and surrounding areas yesterday, a day after a dust storm and moderate rain lashed parts of the national capital.The storm caused huge damage in some parts of the capital with branches of trees falling on roads, cars.Power supply across Delhi-NCR was also affected after branches of trees and other objects fell on the electrical lines. The India Meteorological Department has issued a weather alert in Delhi for thunderstorms and lightning throughout the day.The adverse weather brought flight operations at airports to a near standstill, leaving hundreds of passengers stranded for hours and triggering a wave of complaints on social media over airline mismanagement.Airport sources told foreign media that there was a sudden spike in crowding at boarding gates late Friday night and early Saturday due to diverted and delayed flights landing at the same time. Source: Indian Media

title: Two Dead Bodies Discovered in Two Separate Locations in Hali-Ela, Badulla
content: Two dead bodies have been found in two separate locations in Hali-Ela, Badulla.One body was discovered in a drain along the Ketawala Road in the Hali-Ela town.The other body was found on a road near the railway station on the Hali-Ela-Bandarawela road.The deceased individuals are 49 and 61 years old.The cause of their deaths is yet to be determined, and the bodies have been placed in the Badulla Hospital mortuary for post-mortem examination.

title: Pillayan to Be Detained and Interrogated For 90 Days
content: The Criminal Investigation Department has obtained approval to detain and interrogate Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan, alias Pillayan, for a period of 90 days. He was arrested in Batticaloa on April 8 in connection with an abduction and missing persons case.Public Security Minister Ananda Wijepala, speaking in Parliament recently, stated that significant information has emerged suggesting Pillayan s involvement in the 2019 Easter Sunday attacks.Pillayan previously served as the Chief Minister of the Eastern Province and later held the position of State Minister under former administrations.

title: One-month Grace Period To Implement Pending Parliamentary Recommendations
content: The Committee to Review the Non-Implementation of Parliamentary Committee Recommendations has decided to grant a one-month grace period for responsible institutions to implement outstanding recommendations made by various parliamentary committees.The decision was reached during a meeting held in Parliament under the chairmanship of Minister Attorney Harshana Nanayakkara. The committee also discussed prioritizing the most critical unimplemented recommendations for review.It was revealed that over 80 recommendations made by the Committee on Public Petitions during the fifth session of the ninth Parliament remain unimplemented. The same one-month grace period will apply to pending recommendations issued by the Committee on Public Enterprises COPE, the Committee on Public Accounts COPA, and the Committee on Public Finance.Letters will be sent to the relevant ministry secretaries, urging the immediate implementation of these recommendations.Institutions that are unable to comply within the set timeframe must provide written explanations to the committee.

title: AG Files Fresh Indictments Against Yoshitha Rajapaksa and Daisy Forrest
content: The Attorney General has once again filed indictments before the Colombo High Court against Yoshitha Rajapaksa and his grandmother, Daisy Forrest, over a joint bank account holding Rs. 59 million with an undisclosed source of funds.Investigations have revealed that Daisy Forrest does not possess any known assets and is financially dependent on the Rajapaksa family.The Attorney General had previously filed similar charges under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act in connection with the same account.

title: World Journalists Conference 2025: Navigating Journalism in the Age of AI and Climate Change
content: Journalism has long stood as a cornerstone of democratic societies, serving as both a mirror and a watchdog. In an era marked by rapid technological advancements and pressing global challenges, the role of journalists becomes ever more pivotal. Organized by the prestigious Journalists Association of Korea, the World Journalists Conference 2025 WJC 2025, held from March 31 to April 4 across Seoul and other major cities in South Korea, brought together Journalists from over 50 countries to deliberate on the evolving landscape of journalism. A Word About The Journalists Association of Korea: A Pillar of Press FreedomEstablished on August 17, 1964, the Journalists Association of Korea JAK emerged as a unified response against the Press Ethics Commission Law, which sought to institutionalize governmental interference in the media. Over the decades, JAK has grown into South Korea s largest organization of professional journalists, boasting a membership exceeding 12,000 individuals from 209 media outlets spanning newspapers, broadcasting, telecommunications, and digital platforms. As it approaches its 61st anniversary, JAK continues to champion press freedom, uphold journalistic ethics, and foster international collaboration among media professionals. Conference 1: Shaping the Future of Journalism in the AI Media Era; Copyrights and Ethical ChallengesThe inaugural session of WJC 2025, held at the Korea Press Institute in Seoul, centered on the theme Shaping the Future of Journalism in the AI Media Era: Copyright and Ethical Challenges. Moderated by Lee Joo Hee, Managing Editor of The Korea Herald, the session featured insights from Yin Cao China Daily, China, Hwang Seok-ha Busan Daily News, Korea, Natalia Szewczak Business Insider Poland, Poland, and Diana Fuentes Investigative Reporters and Editors, USA. Yin Cao: The Role of AI in Journalism; Balancing Efficiency and Integrity in the AI Era Yin Cao highlighted the transformative impact of AI tools like ChatGPT and Deepseek in streamlining journalistic tasks such as drafting, content personalization, and multimedia generation. She emphasized the efficiency gains AI offers, including rapid transcription of interviews and headline suggestions. However, she cautioned against potential pitfalls: Misinformation: AI s capacity to generate content can inadvertently spread false information if not properly vetted. Copyright Infringement: The use of data scraped from the internet without appropriate permissions raises legal and ethical concerns. Privacy Violations: Instances of voice cloning without consent underscore the need for stringent privacy safeguards. Deepfakes and Fraud: The potential misuse of AI to deceive the public poses threats to trust and democratic processes.To mitigate these risks, Cao advocated for clear newsroom policies on AI usage, transparency regarding AI-generated content, robust regulations to protect creators rights, and ongoing education on AI governance. She concluded, Journalists who fail to adapt and critically engage with AI tools risk obsolescence. Embracing AI sensibly can enhance our craft and reaffirm our value. Hwang Seok-ha: Journalism in the AI Era; The Intersection of Efficiency, Ethics CopyrightDrawing from his experience covering baseball, Hwang Seok-ha discussed leveraging AI for data analysis in sports reporting. Confronted with complex player statistics predominantly in English abbreviations, he utilized ChatGPT to interpret and analyze the data. While acknowledging AI s utility in handling numerical data, Hwang warned against overreliance, citing instances where AI-generated content contained inaccuracies a phenomenon known as hallucination. He stressed the necessity of fact-checking AI outputs against verified sources to maintain journalistic integrity.Referencing Gannett s policies, Hwang emphasized the importance of transparency, accuracy, fairness, and accountability when incorporating AI into journalism. He asserted that journalists bear the ultimate responsibility for AI-assisted reporting and must promptly correct any errors to uphold credibility. He concluded, Without clear legal safeguards, there is a high risk of jeopardizing the sustainability of journalism. Therefore, it is crucial to establish institutional frameworks that ensure fair compensation when AI trains on and utilizes news articles." Diana Fuentes: The New Life of AI in the 21st CenturyDiana Fuentes highlighted AI s potential to enhance investigative journalism. She cited The New York Times use of AI to condense over 500 hours of election misinformation recordings into five hours of analyzable content, demonstrating AI s capacity to streamline data processing. Fuentes underscored the importance of transparency in AI usage, advocating for clear disclosures to maintain public trust. Trust and credibility are difficult to earn. Unfortunately, it is all too easy to lose, she said adding to it Knowledge is power. We should be willing to share that power. Diana also highlighted the role of organizations like Investigative Reporters and Editors IRE in training journalists on the ethical use of AI. She praised their efforts to balance innovation with responsibility: Humans need to be involved all along the way. She concluded with a call for unity and collaboration: We need to use all available tools and work together on behalf of our communities. Opening Ceremony:Following Conference 1, the official opening ceremony commenced with an address by JAK President Park Jong Hyun, who underscored the pressing issues of AI integration and climate change as challenges requiring collective action from the international press. Congratulatory speeches were later delivered by National Assembly Speaker Woo Won Shik Virtually and Minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism Yu In Chon. An official luncheon organized by the JAK at the National Press Club provided 65 Journalists from 52 Countries with an opportunity to network and reflect on the discussions. Conference 2: The Role of Journalism in Confronting Climate ChangeResuming after the luncheon, Conference 2 focused on The Role of Journalism in Confronting Climate Change and Environmental Shifts. Moderated by Park Sang Wook of JTBC Korea, the panel featured Murray Webster CBC, Canada, Tsegahun Asefa Shimekit NBC Ethiopia TV, Gianmarco Volpe Agenzia Nova, Italy, and Yun Ji Ro Next Group, Korea. Murray Webster: Reframing Climate ReportingMurray Webster, a Senior Defence and Foreign Policy Correspondent representing CBC, Canada urged journalists to reframe climate change narratives by highlighting its implications for national security. Webster emphasized that climate change is a driver of geopolitics, citing its links to natural disasters, refugee flows, and conflicts over resources: Climate change is becoming a driver of geopolitics whether it is the melting of polar ice cap in the Arctic; raging wildfires in the North or more recently California; natural disasters; droughts and food insecurity that lead to mass migration. Webster further referenced the 2008 US National Security Assessment and 2015 White House Strategy, both of which warned of the security implications of climate change warnings that are now playing out globally.He added in his speech on NATO s and the EU s late but growing recognition of climate as a security threat and pointed to the Arctic s rising strategic importance.He concluded, We live in perilous times environmentally and now geopolitically. Climate change is spoken about in apocalyptic and existential terms. The apocalypse may be upon us. Although, it may not look entirely like what we have been predicting for the last 20 years. End of the Main Conference:Following the insightful panel discussions, both Conference 1 and Conference 2 at the World Journalists Conference 2025 WJC 2025 featured engaging Q A sessions. After Conference 2, attendees were treated to a special lecture by Pohang City Mayor, Lee Kang Deok. He detailed Pohang s ambitious Greenway Project, initiated in 2016, aimed at transforming the city from a steel industry hub into a sustainable, green urban center. The project encompasses Pohang s commitment to environmental sustainability. The conference concluded with a musical evening featuring South Korean baritone, Claudio Jung. The World Journalists Conference 2025 not only facilitated critical discussions on the evolving landscape of journalism and pressing global issues but also celebrated cultural diversity and sustainable initiatives. While the main conference of the World Journalists Conference 2025 WJC 2025 concluded in Seoul, the event s agenda extended beyond the capital, offering participants immersive experiences across South Korea. Participants had the opportunity of visiting several major cities, including Jeju Island, Suwon, Anseong, Songdo, and Incheon, each providing unique insights into the nation s cultural heritage and advancements.

title: Special Transport Services for Sinhala and Tamil New Year
content: Special passenger transport services are in operation today to facilitate travel for those heading to their hometowns for the Sinhala and Tamil New Year.Special bus services have been deployed from major cities including Kandy, Puttalam, High Level Low Level routes, Dambulla, and Galle.Additional expressway buses are running to destinations such as Galle, Matara, Badulla, Tangalle, and Kataragama, with services operating from key transit hubs including Makumbura, Kadawatha, Kaduwela, and Bastian Mawatha.Meanwhile, the Department of Railways has launched 40 special train services.These trains will operate to Badulla, Beliatta, Anuradhapura, Galle, and Kankesanturai. The number of carriages on trains like the Yal Devi and Rajarata Rajina has also been increased.

title: LG Elections: Ballot Paper Printing Nears Completion
content: Government Printer Pradeep Pushpakumara says that the printing of over one million ballot papers for 14 administrative districts has been completed.Printing for the remaining 11 districts is ongoing and is expected to be completed by the 28th of April.Meanwhile, Postmaster General P. Sathkumara said that approximately 50 percent of the ballot papers for postal voting are expected to be received by Department of Posts.The postal ballots already received are currently being distributed. He also noted that ballot papers for postal voting from local government institutions involved in ongoing court proceedings are anticipated to arrive soon.The Court of Appeal yesterday lifted the interim injunction on 18 local government institutions, including the Colombo Municipal Council, allowing them to proceed with local government elections on May 6th as scheduled.

title: Ministry of Health Warns of Accident Risks During Festive Season
content: The Non-Communicable Diseases Unit of the Ministry of Health is urging the public to take extra precautions to prevent accidents during the festive season.Consultant Community Physician Samitha Sirithunga revealed that annually, between 28,000 and 30,000 individuals are hospitalized due to accidents during the New Year week. He further said that these incidents result in the loss of 75 to 100 lives each year.

title: Celebrating around the world: Share your Sinhala and Tamil New Year moments with us!
content: The Sinhala and Tamil New Year is a valuable festival to celebrate and pass on Sri Lanka's rich heritage to future generations.Even though many Sri Lankans are living abroad, their hearts remain deeply connected to their homeland.Across the world, members of the Sri Lankan diaspora are preparing to celebrate the New Year in their own meaningful ways.Just as those in Sri Lanka observe the New Year with customs, rituals, and festivals, Sri Lankans overseas are also organizing their own New Year celebrations.We invite our Sri Lankan expatriate communities to share those celebrations with us.If you're organizing a New Year event while living abroad, please send information and video footage to WhatsApp number: 071 241 4444.We are ready to feature your celebrations on our social media platforms, helping to showcase how Sri Lankans around the world stay united in tradition.

title: Minister Urges Public to Prioritize Road Safety During Festive Season
content: With millions expected to travel across the country during the festive period, Minister of Transport, Highways, Ports, and Civil Aviation Bimal Rathnayake highlighted the increased risk of road accidents and urged all citizens especially public transport providers to take simple but crucial precautions.He stressed that long-distance routes like Colombo to Anuradhapura and travel on expressways carry a higher risk of serious accidents. He also reminded private vehicle users that safety doesn't end with the driver.According to the Minister, Sri Lanka loses approximately 2,300 lives to road accidents each year, with the festive season often contributing to a tragic spike in those numbers.

title: 1913: Excise Department Launches Hotline to Report Illegal Sale of Alcohol
content: The Excise Department has launched a hotline to report the illegal sale of liquor.Information can be shared with the department via the hotline number 1913.Raids are underway to apprehend individuals involved in the illegal sale of alcohol, following the closure of liquor stores during the holiday season in line with the Sinhala and Tamil New Year.

title: Police Open Fire On Fleeing Stolen Car In Kotahena
content: Police opened fire on a car that was fleeing despite orders to stop in Kotahena last night.It was later revealed that the car had been stolen by a suspect.At about 10:30 PM last night, a man stole a car with two women inside in Wasala Road, Kotahena.A pregnant woman and her mother were inside the car at the time.The woman's husband had stopped the car and gone into a restaurant on Kotahena Street to buy food.During this time, a suspect broke into the car and drove off, taking the two women along with it.The husband immediately contacted the police to report the theft of the car and his family members.A team of officers from the Mattakkuliya Police Station began pursuing the vehicle.Despite police signals to stop, the suspect continued fleeing, prompting officers to fire two shots at the car in an attempt to bring it to a halt.The suspect eventually abandoned the car near the Bluemendal railway crossing in the Kotahena police division and fled on foot.Fortunately, neither of the women inside the car was injured during the incident.The suspect has not yet been arrested.

title: New Year Wishes From President & Prime Minister
content: President Anura Kumara Dissanayake has called on the people to join in making the national transformation program a success a program aimed at ushering in essential economic, social, and political change for the country.In his New Year message, the President invited all Sri Lankans to come together in strength and solidarity, united by a shared purpose: to uplift the nation and improve the lives of its people.The message emphasized that the core spirit of New Year traditions is the renewal of life to shape individuals who are free from regressive attitudes and outdated thinking.He added that the New Year becomes truly meaningful when it marks the beginning of personal and collective renewal.Prime Minister Dr. Harini Amarasuriya has also extended her greetings for the Sinhala and Tamil New Year.In her message, the Prime Minister expressed hope that the people of Sri Lanka will find the strength, unity, and energy needed for transformation and a more prosperous future.She called on the public to embrace the New Year with respect, peace, and compassion and to carry these values into their daily lives and communities.

title: Six Complaints Over Election Laws Violation In 24 Hours
content: Within the past 24 hours, six complaints regarding election law violations have been filed.According to the Police, 05 criminal offenses were also reported. A total of 122 complaints related to election law violations have been received from the 3rd of March to date.The total number of criminal offenses reported is 32.14 candidates and 46 accomplices have also been arrested for violation of election laws during this period.

title: Another Suspect Involved In Devinuwara Shooting Arrested
content: A T56 firearm allegedly used in the shooting incident, which was carried out close to the Devinuwara Devalaya in Gandara, Matara, has been recovered.The firearm was recovered following the arrest of another suspect believed to be involved in the incident. Previously, a suspect allegedly involved in the same incident was also arrested with a T56 firearm.The recovery of the firearm and the arrest were made following interrogation of the suspect previously arrested.The shooting occurred near the Devinuwara Sri Vishnu Devalaya on Sinhasana Road, targeting two individuals traveling on a motorcycle on the 21st of March.

title: A/L Results Expected After New Year Holidays
content: The Department of Examinations says that the results of the Advanced Level examination will be released after April 20th.The results were initially scheduled to be released before April 20th. However, due to several practical issues, the Department said that the release has been delayed.A total of 333,185 candidates sat for the Advanced Level examination this year.

title: Police Crack Down on Drugs and Drunk Driving; 35,000 Officers Deployed During Festive Season
content: Minister of Public Security and Parliamentary Affairs Ananda Wijepala said that the Police have intensified drug raids across the Sri Lanka during the festive season.He said that special operations are also being carried out to identify and apprehend drunk drivers.The Minister urged the public to take necessary precautions to reduce the risk of accidents during the New Year celebrations.More than 35,000 police officers have been deployed islandwide to ensure security during the festive season.

title: Extra Transport Arranged For Sinhala And Tamil New Year
content: Special transport services are in operation today for people traveling to their hometowns for the Sinhala and Tamil New Year.Deputy General Manager Operations of the Sri Lanka Transport Board, T. H. R. T. Chandrasiri, stated that additional buses have been arranged and will be operated as required.Meanwhile, the Department of Railways is also operating special train services today for the convenience of New Year travelers.Accordingly, 40 additional train services will run to destinations including Badulla, Beliatta, Anuradhapura, Galle, and Kankesanthurai. The number of carriages in the Yal Devi and Rajarata Rajina trains has also been increased.

title: Three Suspects In Possession Of Kush And Hashish Arrested By Customs
content: Three Sri Lankan nationals in possession of Kush and Hashish have been arrested by officials of the Narcotics Control Unit of the Sri Lanka Customs.According to Customs, the suspects were arrested following inspections conducted by officials as the suspects attempted to flee the area after arriving in the country from Bangkok.During the inspection, the stock of drugs was discovered concealed in biscuits and bags of chips.Accordingly, 1 kilogram and 616 grams of Kush and 1 kilogram and 1,762 grams of Hashish were taken into custody.Sri Lanka customs stated that the seized drugs were worth approximately 45 million rupees.Two suspects were identified as residents of Colombo, while the other is a resident of Badulla.

title: Police Launch Operation Against Drug Trafficking
content: A police operation has been launched to arrest drug traffickers.The operation, which began yesterday, will involve permanent and temporary roadblocks, raids, and patrols.The assistance of the Police Special Task Force and military personnel will also be obtained as per requirements.

title: Close to 900 Officers Deployed For Raids On Illegal Liquor
content: The Excise Department says approximately 900 officers have been deployed for raids on illegal liquor during the New Year season.The department stated that 58 excise units, 5 special operations units, and approximately 900 excise officers conducted operations covering the entire island.According to the department, public complaints have been of immense support in successful raids preventing offenses related to liquor, drugs, and cigarettes.Information can be shared with the department via the hotline numbers 1913 and 011 2 877 688.

title: Limited Passport Services During New Year Week
content: The Department of Immigration and Emigration says that the issuance of tokens for one-day and regular passport services will be restricted on April 15, 16, and 17.According to the Department, services on those days will only be available until 12 noon.It also stated that the 24-hour service provided under the one-day passport service will not be in operation during this period.

title: Safety Tips for a Joyful and Accident-Free New Year
content: The Ministry of Health has issued a public advisory to prevent accidents during the festive season. Dr. Samitha Sirithunga, a community health specialist from the Non-Communicable Diseases Unit, stated that every year, between 75 and 100 individuals lose their lives due to accidents during the New Year week.In light of this, the authorities have shared several important messages for those celebrating the New Year:The festive season often brings unpleasant memories of increased road accidents and emergencies. This reminder is issued because your life is valuable to us.When traveling long distances to visit friends and family during the New Year, please exercise caution. Under no circumstances should you drive under the influence of alcohol. Not driving under the influence is your responsibility as a driver, and rejecting drunk driving is everyone's responsibility.We urge you not to drive at excessive speeds. Be extremely cautious when swimming near reservoirs. Follow safety measures when lighting fireworks. Ensure that adults supervise children using fireworks.Please be mindful of these precautions. Do not let the joy of the New Year slip away from you.

title: Nearly 1,000 SLTB Staff Reassigned To Meet New Year Demand
content: The Ministry of Transport says that nearly 1,000 SLTB drivers and conductors who had been removed from regular duties due to disciplinary issues have been reassigned to Avurudu passenger transport services.The Ministry emphasized that disciplinary investigations against the concerned staff members will continue despite their temporary reassignment.In addition, around 200 buses that had previously been removed from service have been repaired and returned to operation to support New Year transport needs.

title: Extra Buses, Trains for New Year; 35,000 Cops On Duty
content: In celebration of the Sinhala and Tamil New Year, special transport services are being implemented today. According to T.H.R.T. Chandrasiri, Deputy General Manager of the Sri Lanka Transport Board, additional buses have been scheduled to meet passenger demand.Sri Lanka Railways is also operating special train services for the New Year. Extra train journeys are available to Badulla, Beliatta, Anuradhapura, Galle, and Kankesanthurai. Additionally, the number of carriages on the Yal Devi and Rajarata Rejina trains has been increased.In anticipation of the New Year festivities, Sri Lanka Police implemented special security and traffic arrangements in areas where large crowds are expected to gather. These measures are in place for festivals, musical shows, and other celebrations.The police have deployed 6,000 officers in areas such as Colombo Fort, Pettah, Borella, Kirulapone, and Bambalapitiya, as well as around religious sites, to ensure public safety. Overall, more than 35,000 police officers have been assigned to manage security and traffic during the festive period.

title: North Korea Building Its Largest, Most Advanced Warship Ever
content: CNN New satellite images show what could be North Korea s biggest warship ever possibly more than double the size of anything in leader Kim Jong Un s naval fleet. Images taken by independent satellite providers Maxar Technologies and Planet Labs on April 6 show the ship under construction in the water at the Nampo shipyard on North Korea s west coast, about 60 kilometers 37 miles southwest of the capital Pyongyang. Analysts say the pictures show ongoing construction of weapons and other internal systems of the ship, which is likely a guided-missile frigate FFG designed to carry missiles in vertical launch tubes for use against targets on land and sea. The FFG is approximately 140 meters 459 feet long, making it the largest warship manufactured in North Korea, an analysis by Joseph Bermudez Jr. and Jennifer Jun at the Center for Strategic and International Studies said. For comparison, the US Navy s Arleigh Burke-class destroyers are about 505 feet long and its under-construction Constellation-class frigates will be 496 feet long. The existence of the warship is not a surprise. The Kim regime has been engaged in a rapid modernization of its armed forces, developing a range of new weapons and testing intercontinental ballistic missiles that can reach almost anywhere in the United States. Kim Duk-ki, a retired South Korean admiral, said he thinks Moscow may be providing the technology for the frigate s missile systems. Pictures of the vessel appeared in a report by state-run Korean Central Television released late last year on the ruling Workers Party s end-of-year plenary session. The images showed leader Kim inspecting the ship s construction. The images shown in the KCTV video show the warship could have the kind of weaponry possessed by modern navies, including vertical launch cells that could be used to fire a variety of missiles. Analysts also noted the ship seems to be set up to have phased-array radar, which can track threats and targets more quickly and accurately than previously displayed North Korean capabilities. Despite those indications of advanced warfighting abilities, analysts urged caution in making assumptions.

title: President, PM, And Opposition Leader Extend New Year Greetings
content: President Anura Kumara Dissanayake has called on the public to unite in building a new beginning for the nation through the ongoing national program aimed at bringing about economic, social, and political transformation.In his Sinhala and Tamil New Year message, the President invited the people to work together in unity towards a common goal to uplift the country and its people.He emphasized that the true meaning of New Year traditions lies in renewing one s life and creating a society free from regressive thinking and attitudes. The President added that this moment marks a real opportunity for a fresh start.Meanwhile, Prime Minister Dr. Harini Amarasuriya, in her New Year message, wished the Sri Lankan people a transformation filled with new energy, unity, and prosperity for a better future.She urged citizens to begin the New Year with respect, peace, and compassion within their communities.Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, also issuing a New Year message, said that the nation faces both familiar and new challenges in the coming year. He stated that it is the collective responsibility of all to address these challenges and move the country forward.

title: President Dissanayake Vows to Unite Sri Lanka, End Ethnic Divisions
content: President Anura Kumara Dissanayake promised to eliminate ethnic divisions in Sri Lanka during a rally in Kinniya on Saturday 12.The event, part of the National People's Power NPP campaign for the upcoming local government elections, saw a large turnout of supporters.In his speech, the President reflected on how politics in Sri Lanka has traditionally been divided along ethnic lines, with different communities voting for parties that represent their group. "For too long, our politics has been about division. But the recent elections showed that people from all regions North, East, and South are coming together," he said. "This is the change we need. We are moving beyond ethnic politics."He also addressed critics who claim that the NPP has not done enough for the Muslim community."Those who seek division are the ones criticizing us. But we will not let that happen," he said.The President assured the crowd that his government is committed to maintaining peace and justice for everyone.

title: Three Access Routes Announced for Devotees Attending Sri Dalada Vandana
content: COLOMBO News 1st Three designated access routes have been announced for devotees attending the Sri Dalada Vandana sacred pilgrimage starting on the 18th. The three entry routes to the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic are as follows: 1. The queuing path set up from D.S. Senanayake Street Trincomalee Street side up to the entrance of the Sri Dalada Maligawa. 2. The queuing path starting from the Red Bridge area Rathu Bokkuwa, passing along Sangharaja Mawatha around the Kandy Lake, leading to the main entrance of the temple. 3. Another queuing path also starting from the Red Bridge area, going around the Maligawa premises by the Kandy Lake, and reaching the temple s main entrance. Devotees can use any of these designated paths to visit the temple for the upcoming Dalada Vandana.

title: Will The Erythrina or Erabudu Tree, Become A Memory Of The Past?
content: COLOMBO News 1st The Erythrina tree, locally known as 'Erabudu', adds a unique charm to the New Year celebrations.Traditionally, two types of Erythrina trees have adorned Sri Lanka's historic villages during the New Year: the Erythrina variegata and the Erythrina fusca, known locally as the Erabudu and Yak Erythrina, respectively.These trees, scientifically named Erythrina variegata and Erythrina fusca, were once widespread in the country.Typically, the leaves of these trees begin to fall as they start to bloom in April. The sight of these trees covered in beautiful red flowers is truly enchanting. However, this stunning view has become increasingly rare in recent times due to the gradual decline of the Erythrina tree population."When we investigated the cause, we found that in 2006, a species of insect known as the Erythrina Gall Wasp was reported in Sri Lanka. The damage caused by this insect is believed to be responsible for the decline of these trees. Additionally, unlike in the past, Erythrina trees are no longer planted as fences. Nowadays, walls are built instead of fences, and as a result, these trees are gradually disappearing from our surroundings," exaplained Professor Cyril Wijesundara, a Botanist. The Erythrina tree is not only aesthetically pleasing but also holds medicinal value."This tree is important for its beauty and cultural significance, as well as its medicinal properties. In traditional Sri Lankan medicine, Erythrina leaves, bark, and seeds are used. They are used for various ailments, including skin conditions and as an anti-cancer treatment. The tree also provides shade in tea plantations. It is a very important tree found in tropical countries," he noted.Given the significance of the Erythrina tree, it is crucial to scientifically confirm the relationship between its decline and the Erythrina Gall Wasp, or other potential factors. This responsibility falls on our country's researchers.Furthermore, based on scientific research, it is the duty of the authorities to take appropriate measures to conserve this tree. If not, the Erythrina tree, which doubles the beauty of the New Year season, will become nothing more than a memory of the past.

title: Chief Gunman of 'Karandeniya Sudda's Gang Arrested
content: The main gunman of the organized crime gang led by "Karandeniya Sudda" has been arrested. The Criminal Investigation Department apprehended the suspect this morning at the Bandaranaike International Airport. He was attempting to flee to Thailand using a forged passport. The suspect is accused of the recent murder of a retired officer from the Boossa Prison, who was shot dead in front of his house. The 31-year-old suspect is a resident of Ambalangoda. Police stated that he tried to escape the country using a forged passport under the name Lakindu Sandeep Bandara. The police further mentioned that the suspect is wanted in connection with several murders and financial frauds in the Galle and Ambalangoda police divisions.

title: Police Hunt For High-Level Road Street Racers
content: Sri Lanka Police launched an investigation into a group of motorists who drove recklessly and endangered the public on High-Level Road.Senior Police Superintendent Buddhika Manathunga, the police spokesperson, stated that the vehicles involved have been identified.A video showing these vehicles driving irresponsibly on High-Level Road on the night of the 13th is currently circulating on social media.The police have announced that legal action will be taken against all individuals involved in the illegal street racing.

title: 26-Year-Old Fatally Stabbed Over Dispute
content: A man was fatally stabbed with a sharp weapon in the Kotagepitiya area in Galaha.The police reported that the victim was a 26-year-old man.The murder is believed to have been the result of a longstanding dispute.The police have arrested a 36-year-old suspect from the Kolabissa area in connection with the murder.

title: Elephants Encircle Young in 'Alert Circle' During Quake
content: On Monday morning, Southern California experienced a 5.2-magnitude earthquake that caused boulders to tumble onto rural roads outside San Diego and items to fall off shelves. Amid the tremors, a remarkable scene unfolded at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park. A herd of African elephants, including Ndlula, Umngani, Khosi, and the young Zuli and Mkhaya, instinctively formed a protective circle around their calves. This behavior, known as an alert circle, is a natural response to perceived threats, as elephants can sense vibrations through their feet. The herd's quick action to safeguard their young was captured on video, displaying their strong familial bonds and protective instincts. After several minutes, the elephants appeared to calm down, reassured that the danger had passed. Fortunately, officials reported no injuries or major damage from the earthquake.

title: Singapore General Election On 3rd May
content: Singapore will head to the polls on 3 May, in what will be the first electoral test for its new prime minister Lawrence Wong. The election campaign, which lasts just nine days, is expected to be dominated by the rising cost of living, housing needs, jobs, and a growing demand for healthcare amid an ageing population. Voters are widely expected to return the ruling People's Action Party PAP to power. The PAP has won every election since Singapore was granted self rule by the British in 1959. The country's last election in 2020 saw the opposition Workers' Party secure 10 seats - the biggest victory for the opposition since Singapore gained independence in 1965. This time, ninety-seven seats are up for grabs. Though the PAP won 83 out of 93 seats in 2020, it will no doubt be looking for a stronger win this year - with the last election seen as a setback for the party. According to a Reuters report citing data from pollster YouGov, 44 of 1,845 Singaporeans surveyed in March have decided who to vote for. Of that number, 63 say they would choose the ruling party and 15 would back the leading opposition Workers' Party. The election is being seen as the first real test of Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, who took office last year - replacing the city state's long-serving premier Lee Hsien Loong, who served as leader for 20 years. Presenting his first budget as the country's leader in February, Wong unveiled a series of tax rebates, handouts and sector-specific measures to cushion against cost-of-living pressures - in what some analysts call a "feel good" budget aimed at sweetening the ground before the election. Since becoming an independent nation in 1965, Singapore has only had four prime ministers - all from the ruling People's Action Party PAP. The first was Mr Lee's father, Lee Kuan Yew, who is widely considered as the founder of modern Singapore and led the country for 25 years. Singapore's political landscape has been dominated by the PAP, though the party was rocked by a series of scandals in 2020 - including a senior minister's arrest in a corruption probe as well as the resignation of two lawmakers over an extramarital affair. Voting is compulsory for Singapore's 2.75 million eligible citizens. Singapore mirrors the UK's first-past-the-post voting system, but there are key differences that make it harder for opposition parties. MPs contest for constituencies that vary in size and the larger ones are not represented by an individual MP, but by a team of up to five MPs - called Group Representative Constituencies GRCs. The system was introduced in 1988 as a way to include more representation from Singapore's minority groups in the predominantly Chinese city - so parties could "risk" running one or two minority candidates. But until several years ago, opposition parties have not had the resources to recruit enough skilled and experienced people to genuinely contest these larger constituencies. Candidates must also deposit S 13,500 9,700: 7,700 to contest and need to win more than one-eighth of total votes to get it back. The electoral divisions of constituencies are also often changed to reflect population growth - opposition parties say this is not done transparently and amounts to gerrymandering, something the government has always denied. Source: BBC

title: Expressway Revenue Surpasses Rs. 170 Mn in Just Four Days
content: The revenue generated from expressways over the past four days has exceeded Rs. 170 million.During this period, the number of vehicles that traveled on the expressways totaled 497,223.The highest number of vehicles traveled on the expressways on the 11th of this month.On that day, 163,541 vehicles used the expressways, generating a revenue of Rs. 54,666,450.

title: 59 Complaints of Election Law Violations and Crimes
content: Sri Lanka Police reported receiving 159 complaints related to election law violations and criminal activities concerning the local government elections.Among these complaints, 32 are related to criminal activities, while 127 pertain to violations of election laws.In connection with these complaints, 15 candidates and 52 supporters have been arrested, and 12 vehicles have been taken into police custody.

title: Health Inspectors Deployed for Siri Dalada Wandanawa
content: In preparation for the Siri Dalada Wandanawa, or the Sacred Veneration Of The Tooth Relic Of Lord Buddha, special health measures have been implemented to ensure the safety of the devotees arriving in Kandy. The Public Health Inspectors' Association has announced that approximately 50 public health inspectors will be deployed daily to oversee these measures.According to the statement released by the association, all food establishments in the city will be inspected by public health inspectors to ensure maximum food safety. Additionally, all alms centers dansals must be registered with the Kandy Municipal Council's Health Department.To further safeguard the health of the devotees, a 24-hour water supply system will be operational, with the water being tested every hour.

title: Restraining Order Issued to Stop Defamation of Retired Major General
content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Manjula Ratnayake has issued a conditional restraining order to prevent the dissemination of false and defamatory statements about retired Major General Ashoka Thoradeniya through electronic, print, and social media. The order, effective until April 30th, was issued against Rahubadda Kankanamge Indrananda de Silva. The magistrate also ordered Indrananda de Silva to present his case in court on April 30th. This decision was made under Section 24 of the Online Safety Act No. 9 of 2024, following a complaint by Major General Thoradeniya. President's Counsel Sanjay Rajaratnam and Attorney-at-Law Sudath Jayasundara argued that the statements made about Major General Thoradeniya violated Sections 24 and 12 of the Online Safety Act. They requested a restraining order to prevent further dissemination of these statements. After considering the arguments, the Additional Magistrate issued the restraining order.

title: Kandy Fortified: Over 10,000 Security Personnel Deployed For Siri Dalada Wandanawa
content: In preparation for the Siri Dalada Relic Exposition, Sri Lanka Police have announced the deployment of over 10,000 police and security personnel to ensure the safety and security of the city. This significant increase in security presence includes more than 8,000 police officers and over 1,100 military personnel.Due to the Siri Dalada Relic Exposition, 37 schools within the Kandy city limits will be closed from April 21st to 25th, as announced by the Central Province Education Department. The Siri Dalada Relic Exposition, scheduled to take place from April 18th to 28th, is a significant cultural event that draws large crowds, necessitating these measures.In addition to the school closures, three new access routes have been introduced by the Dalada Maligawa or the Temple of The Sacred Tooth Relic to facilitate the movement of devotees:1. From D.S. Senanayake Street to the Dalada Maligawa's main entrance.2. From Ratubokkuwa through the Kandy Lake roundabout Sangharaja Mawatha to the main entrance.3. From Ratubokkuwa through the Kandy Lake roundabout Maligawa area to the main entrance.To accommodate the influx of visitors, the Sri Lanka Transport Board has announced the deployment of 150 additional buses from various regions across the country. Furthermore, Sri Lanka Railways has planned special train services from Colombo and other areas to Kandy during this period.

title: 153-Year-Old Tortoise Anointed Oil at Dehiwala Zoo
content: The Dehiwala National Zoological Gardens hosted a special oil anointing ceremony, marking a significant cultural tradition. Among the participants was Sri Lanka's oldest living animal, a 153-year-old giant tortoise, who stole the spotlight with its presence. The ceremony, held amidst the lush greenery of the zoo, attracted many visitors. The giant tortoise, revered for its longevity and symbolic representation of wisdom and resilience, was gently anointed with oil, following the traditional practices that aim to bless and protect the animals. The Sinhala and Tamil New Year, celebrated in April, is one of the most significant cultural events in Sri Lanka. Among the various traditions observed during this festive period, the oil anointing ceremony holds a special place. The oil anointing ceremony, known as "Hisa Thel Gaema," is performed to invoke blessings of good health and prosperity for the coming year. This ritual typically takes place at an auspicious time, which is determined by astrologers. his ritual is often led by religious leaders and is accompanied by the chanting of blessings. The oil anointing ceremony is not just a religious practice but also a communal event that brings families and communities together. The ceremony is widely observed across the country, with notable events held at historic temples and cultural sites.

content: Due to the Siri Dalada Relic Exposition, 37 schools within the Kandy city limits will be closed from April 21st to 25th, as announced by the Central Province Education Department. The Siri Dalada Relic Exposition, scheduled to take place from April 18th to 28th, is a significant cultural event that draws large crowds, necessitating these measures.In addition to the school closures, three new access routes have been introduced by the Dalada Maligawa or the Temple of The Sacred Tooth Relic to facilitate the movement of devotees:1.
